patterns.content: LEA (Lightweight Encryption Algorithm) is a 128-bit block cipher developed by ETRI/NSR (Korea) in 2013 for high-speed encryption. Block size: 128 bits. Key sizes: 128, 192, 256 bits. Rounds: 24, 28, 32 (depending on key size). Structure: ARX (Addition-Rotation-XOR) design for fast software implementation. Quantum resistance: 256-bit key provides 128-bit security against Grover's algorithm.
patterns.quantum_resistance: LEA-256 recommended for quantum resistance (128-bit effective security)

patterns.content: LEA implementation patterns: import lea, from lea import LEA, LEA_encrypt(), LEA_decrypt(), lea.new(key, mode). High-performance libraries optimized for x86/ARM processors. Common in Korean crypto frameworks.

LEA in configuration files: cipher: LEA-256-GCM, encryption_algorithm: LEA, fast_cipher: LEA-256. TLS cipher suites: TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_LEA_256_GCM_SHA384. Commonly used in Korean government/enterprise systems.
patterns.note: LEA-256-GCM is recommended for AEAD and quantum resistance

patterns.content: LEA binary signatures: LEA_Encrypt, LEA_Decrypt, LEA_KeySchedule, LEA_EncRound function names. ARX operations: ADD (add), ROL/ROR (rotate), XOR. Round constants delta array. Optimized for 32-bit/64-bit processors.

LEA performance characteristics: 1.5-2x faster than AES on software without AES-NI. Optimized for Intel/AMD/ARM processors. 128-bit block operations with efficient key schedule. Ideal for high-throughput applications (VPN, disk encryption).
patterns.note: Speed advantage makes it attractive for bulk encryption

patterns.content: LEA quantum vulnerability: LEA-128 provides 64-bit security, LEA-192 provides 96-bit, LEA-256 provides 128-bit against quantum computers (Grover's algorithm). LEA-256 is quantum-resistant for foreseeable future. No structural weaknesses found in current cryptanalysis.
patterns.recommendation: Use LEA-256 for long-term security, LEA-256-GCM for AEAD

patterns.content: LEA standards: Korean standard KS X 1213-1 (2014), ISO/IEC 29192-2:2019 (Lightweight cryptography - Block ciphers), IETF RFC 8998 (LEA Cipher Suites for TLS), Validated by CRYPTREC.

LEA usage context: Korean government cloud services, enterprise VPN, database encryption (TDE), file/disk encryption, IoT gateways, secure messaging. Alternative to AES in performance-critical applications. Widely adopted in Korea.

LEA detection priorities: HIGH - LEA-128 in long-term storage (upgrade to LEA-256), MEDIUM - ECB mode usage (use GCM/CTR), LOW - LEA-256-GCM with proper nonce management. Check key size and mode of operation.
